question: Should the United States use private military firms abroad to pursue its military objectives?

content.source_1: Congressional Research Service — “Department of Defense’s Use of Contractors to Support Military Operations: Background, Analysis, and Issues for Congress” (Moshe Schwartz, multiple updates 2009–2015). Finding: During peak operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, over 200,000 contractor personnel were deployed and at times outnumbered U.S. troops; DoD cited surge capacity, specialized skills, and flexibility as reasons contractors were “integral” to achieving operational objectives. Source: https://sgp.fas.org/crs/natsec/R40764.pdf
content.source_2: Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs & ICRC — The Montreux Document on pertinent international legal obligations and good practices for States related to operations of private military and security companies during armed conflict (2008; U.S. endorsing state). Evidence: Affirms that using PMCs is not per se unlawful under international law and sets out best practices and state responsibilities, providing a legitimacy framework for states (including the U.S.) to employ PMCs abroad when properly regulated. Source: https://www.icrc.org/en/publication/0996-montreux-document-private-military-and-security-companies
content.source_3: Human Rights Watch — “Iraq: Blackwater Convictions an Important Step for Accountability” (Oct. 22, 2014). Evidence: Details the Nisour Square incident in Baghdad (2007), where Blackwater contractors killed 17 civilians; despite later criminal convictions, HRW highlights enduring accountability gaps and risks of civilian harm when lethal force is outsourced, challenging the justification for PMC use. Source: https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/10/22/iraq-blackwater-convictions-important-step-accountability
content.source_4: Commission on Wartime Contracting in Iraq and Afghanistan — Final Report: “Transforming Wartime Contracting: Controlling Costs, Reducing Risks” (Aug. 2011). Finding: Estimates $31–$60 billion lost to waste and fraud in contingency contracting and warns that overreliance on contractors can undermine mission effectiveness and strategic outcomes, casting doubt on claims of cost efficiency or prudence in using PMCs. Source: https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/GPO-CWC/report.pdf
content.source_5: Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction (SIGIR) — “Hard Lessons: The Iraq Reconstruction Experience” (2009). Evidence: Concludes that private security contractors were essential to protect diplomats, aid workers, and reconstruction teams, enabling the U.S. to sustain diplomatic and reconstruction activities in high-threat environments where uniformed forces were prioritized for combat missions. Source: https://www.sigir.mil/files/USOCO/HardLessons/Hard_Lessons.pdf
content.source_6: Deborah D. Avant — “The Market for Force: The Consequences of Privatizing Security” (Cambridge University Press, 2005). Argument: Privatizing coercive power can erode democratic accountability and civil-military control by shifting force to market logics and diffuse oversight chains, creating incentives misaligned with public objectives—an argument against the normative justification for U.S. reliance on PMCs. Source: https://www.cambridge.org/9780521615358
